results.title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2022 Oscars
results.abstract: The night made history, from That Slap to milestone wins by Troy Kotsur and Ariana DeBose, and a rousing performance by Beyoncé.

multimedia.caption: Ariana DeBose became the first openly queer woman of color to win an acting Oscar.

results.abstract: The complete list of winners for the 94th Academy Awards.

results.title: An Onstage Slap Gives the Oscars More Drama Than It Bargained For
results.abstract: The show strained to offer something for everyone. But it could still create shocking moments.

multimedia.caption: Amy Schumer, Wanda Sykes and Regina Hall hosted an Oscars full of firsts. The show’s most talked-about moment, though, will most likely be the one between Will Smith and Chris Rock.
Amy Schumer, Wanda Sykes and Regina Hall hosted an Oscars full of firsts. The show’s most talked-about moment, though, will most likely be the one between Will Smith and Chris Rock.
Amy Schumer, Wanda Sykes and Regina Hall hosted an Oscars full of firsts. The show’s most talked-about moment, though, will most likely be the one between Will Smith and Chris Rock.

results.title: Onstage Slap Rattles Oscars, Before ‘CODA’ Triumphs
results.abstract: On a night when “CODA” became the first film from a streaming service to win best picture, the focus was on Will Smith’s altercation with Chris Rock.
results.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)

results.title: Will Smith hits Chris Rock after joke about his wife, Jada.
results.abstract: The apparently unscripted moment stunned viewers and audiences alike. The telecast was muted and paused in the United States.

results.title: The Slap Echoes the Morning After the Oscars, Raising Questions
results.abstract: When Will Smith slapped Chris Rock at the Academy Awards for telling a joke about his wife, it divided Hollywood, sparking denunciations, defenses and debates.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs, Matt Stevens and Nicole Sperling

results.title: ‘Drive My Car’ Oscar Is a Slow-Burn Return for Japan’s Cinema
results.abstract: But some of the same qualities that made the film popular overseas have led to a cooler reception domestically.

multimedia.caption: Ryusuke Hamaguchi, right, the director of “Drive My Car,” celebrating on Sunday after the film won an Academy Award for best international feature.

results.title: Will Smith wins his first Oscar moments after hitting Chris Rock onstage.
results.abstract: “Richard Williams was a fierce defender of his family,” Smith said in his acceptance speech, referring to his role in “King Richard.”

multimedia.caption: Will Smith won the best actor Oscar on Sunday for his role in “King Richard.”
Will Smith won the best actor Oscar on Sunday for his role in “King Richard.”
Will Smith won the best actor Oscar on Sunday for his role in “King Richard.”

results.title: Billie Eilish and Finneas win their first Oscar with ‘No Time to Die.’
results.abstract: Their victory came for the theme song from the James Bond film of the same name. The previous two Bond themes also won Oscars.

multimedia.caption: Billie Eilish and Finneas O’Connell won best original song for “No Time to Die.”

results.title: Troy Kotsur makes history as the first deaf man to win an acting Oscar.
results.abstract: “This is dedicated to the deaf community, the CODA community and the disabled community,” he said in his acceptance speech, delivered in American Sign Language. “This is our moment.”

results.title: ‘32 Sounds,’ a Film Performed Live, Probes the Power of Listening
results.abstract: Sam Green’s documentary about the physics and emotions attached to sound comes to BAM with a live score performed by JD Samson and Michael O’Neill.

results.abstract: Mr. Miranda is up for an Academy Award for the song “Dos Oruguitas” from the Disney musical “Encanto.”

results.title: You Don’t Know Much About Jay Penske. And He’s Fine With That.
results.abstract: A quiet Hollywood power broker with a famous name goes on a buying spree that has given him Rolling Stone, South by Southwest and a private island. What more does he want?

results.title: Streaming Took Over Hollywood. Will It Take Best Picture, Too?
results.abstract: A few years ago, the entertainment industry was arguing over whether movies on streaming services even counted as a film. Now, one is poised to win the Oscars’ top prize.
results.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

results.title: Who Will Win Big on Oscar Night?
results.abstract: The 94th annual Academy Awards will be presented on Sunday. Here are our predictions for who will win the biggest awards.

results.title: Regina Hall and Wanda Sykes on Hosting the Oscars
results.abstract: In an interview, the stars said they plan to keep the show moving and make sure it’s funny. But there will be a segment about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

multimedia.caption: Wanda Sykes, left, and Regina Hall at the Loews Hollywood Hotel on Thursday. (Amy Schumer was ill.) They were not fans of the recent hostless Oscar shows.

results.title: Peter Bogdanovich Had a Vision for This Film. Now It’s Finally Being Seen.
results.abstract: “She’s Funny That Way” wasn’t exactly the movie he set out to make, but the director’s cut was feared lost. How it came to be shown at MoMA is a complicated saga.

results.title: Four Best Picture Contenders Are Remakes. Does That Matter to Oscar Voters?
results.abstract: Academy history offers clues about how “Nightmare Alley,” “West Side Story,” “CODA” and “Dune” might fare on Sunday.

results.abstract: A fine British cast is featured in this mildly transgressive love story set in the aftermath of World War I.

results.title: ‘Wood and Water’ Review: The Distances Between Us
results.abstract: In this elegant feature debut about modern alienation, the German writer-director Jonas Bak casts his real-life mother as a retired secretary who travels to Hong Kong to visit her estranged son.
